docs.lead_paragraph: The death rattle is what's so unnerving. People who sit beside someone who is close to death, someone in a stage the experts call ''active dying,'' might hear a sound that's not quite a snore, not quite a gurgle, not quite a rasp. It doesn't hurt; it probably isn't something the dying person is even aware of. But it sounds terrible. ''Once the so-called death rattle starts,'' says Charles G. Meys, a hospice nurse with the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, ''that's usually an indication that the person is not coming back.''

headline.main: Will We Ever Arrive At the Good Death?

docs.snippet: Almost 40 years after the birth of the hospice movement, and despite the rise of living wills and palliative care, the end of life remains anxious and hypermedicalized.

multimedia.credit: Photographs from a study of illness and dying by Nicholas Nixon.
multimedia.caption: As They Died

legacy.MultimediaSummary2: Photographs from a study of illness and dying by Nicholas Nixon.

docs.lead_paragraph: Rafael Palmeiro, the Baltimore Orioles' slugger who defiantly insisted he had never used steroids at a Congressional hearing in March -- jabbing his left index finger at lawmakers to punctuate his denial -- was suspended for 10 days yesterday for violating Major League Baseball's steroids policy. The first star player to fail a test under baseball's recently toughened drug rules, Palmeiro changed his denial yesterday to say he never took steroids intentionally, and he called the positive test an accident.

headline.main: Baseball Bars Longtime Star For Steroid Use

docs.abstract: Rafael Palmeiro, Baltimore Orioles' slugger who defiantly insisted he never used steroids at Congressional hearing in March, becomes first star player to fail Major League Baseball's recently toughened steroid policy, and is suspended for 10 days; he now says he never took steroids intentionally, and he calls positive test an accident; penalty against him, imposed in mid-July, was held in abeyance until arbitrator decided not to overturn it; Major League Baseball reportedly knew that he had failed steroid test when it paid for full-page congratulatory newspaper advertisements when he collected his 3,000th hit on July 15; under major leagues' stricter policy for steroids and other drugs, every player will be tested once, without warning, from start of spring training through end of season, and all players are subject to additional random testing; photos; chronology of events since Aug 2002 collective bargaining agreement under which Major League Baseball and players union agreed, for first time, to test players for steroid use (L)
docs.snippet: Baltimore Orioles slugger Rafael Palmeiro was suspended for 10 days on Monday for violating Major League Baseball's steroids policy.

multimedia.caption: When a Player and Policy Collide
